articles.author: ZEKE MILLER, SEUNG MIN KIM and CHRIS MEGERIAN
articles.description: WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) — Vice President Kamala Harris was closing in Monday on securing the Democratic delegates she needs to become her party's nominee and set a new fundraising record in her first 24 hours as a presidential candidate, as top Democrats rallied to her in their bid to defeat Republican Donald Trump.
articles.title: Harris claims most of the delegates she needs for the nomination, sets new fundraising record

articles.author: ANDREW MELDRUM and JILL LAWLESS
articles.description: KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — U.S. President Joe Biden’s decision to end his campaign for reelection brings a new element of uncertainty for Ukraine, which is struggling to fend off Russian military advances even as it worries about the future of American support.
articles.title: Biden’s withdrawal from the US presidential race spells new uncertainty for Ukraine

articles.author: ALANNA DURKIN RICHER, FARNOUSH AMIRI and CLAUDIA LAUER
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle said Monday that her agency failed in its mission to protect former President Donald Trump, as lawmakers of both major political parties demanded during a highly contentious congressional hearing that she resign over security failures that allowed a gunman to scale a roof and open fire at a campaign rally.
articles.title: Secret Service director, grilled by lawmakers on the Trump assassination attempt, says 'we failed'

articles.author: COLLEEN LONG, SEUNG MIN KIM, ZEKE MILLER and MARY CLARE JALONICK
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — At 1:45 p.m. Sunday, President Joe Biden’s senior staff was notified that he was stepping away from the 2024 race.
articles.title: Biden's decision to drop out crystallized Sunday. His staff knew one minute before the public did

articles.author: ROBERT YOON
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Even before President Joe Biden’s long-speculated withdrawal from the 2024 presidential race, allies of former President Donald Trump floated the possibility of suing to block Democrats from having anyone other than Biden on the ballot in November.
articles.title: GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous'

articles.author: ISABEL DEBRE
articles.description: Joe Biden's withdrawal from the U.S. presidential race injects greater uncertainty into the world at a time when Western leaders are grappling with wars in Ukraine and Gaza, a more assertive China in Asia and the rise of the far right in Europe.
articles.title: Biden's withdrawal injects uncertainty into wars, trade disputes and other foreign policy challenges

articles.author: JOHN O'CONNOR
articles.description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. (AP) — Sonya Massey ducked and apologized to an Illinois sheriff’s deputy only seconds before he shot her three times in her home, with one fatal blow to the head, as seen in body camera video released Monday.
articles.title: Bodycam video reveals chaotic scene of deputy fatally shooting Sonya Massey who called 911 for help

articles.author: WAFAA SHURAFA and MELANIE LIDMAN
articles.description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — The Israeli military ordered the evacuation Monday of part of a crowded area in the Gaza Strip it had designated a humanitarian zone, saying it is planning an operation against Hamas militants there.
articles.title: Israel orders evacuation of part of Gaza humanitarian zone as war's toll passes 39,000 Palestinians

articles.author: CLAIRE SAVAGE
articles.description: As Congressional members on both sides of the aisle grilled U.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle Monday on how a gunman was able to fire shots at former President Donald Trump in an assassination attempt, several Republican lawmakers seized on gender and the agency’s diversity, equity and inclusion efforts as among the reasons for the security failure.
articles.title: Conservatives use shooting at Trump rally to attack DEI efforts at Secret Service

articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. House leaders are calling on CrowdStrike CEO George Kurtz to testify to Congress about the cybersecurity company's role in sparking the widespread tech outage that grounded flights, knocked banks and hospital systems offline and affected services around the world.
articles.title: CrowdStrike CEO called to testify to Congress over cybersecurity's firm role in global tech outage
